docs.lead_paragraph: CHRONIMED INC., -- Minnetonka, Minn., a maker of health care products, said it would buy Transplant Pharmacy, a mail order distribution unit of SangStat Medical, Fremont, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.
docs.snippet: CHRONIMED INC., -- Minnetonka, Minn., a maker of health care products, said it would buy Transplant Pharmacy, a mail order distribution unit of SangStat Medical, Fremont, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the window of her apartment on a hill in Helena, Carrie Villa can see the Sleeping Giant, the mountain formation on the northern horizon that looks just like its name and holds the dream Ms. Villa has been nurturing through 10 hard years. ''I want a house of my own, nothing fancy, on a little piece of land, and that's it,'' said Ms. Villa, a 40-year-old mother of two. Nearly every hour of every day, Ms. Villa thinks about how to squeeze another dollar out of her life so that aging is not just a marathon of dream deferment.

headline.main: A Dream $8.57 an Hour Can't Buy

docs.abstract: Second article in series, Judging the Tax Cut; focuses on how Carrie Villa, 40-year-old mother of two in Helena, Mont, thinks she would be affected by Bush tax cut proposal; although Pres Bush says 'typical family' making $40,000 a year would get $1,600 back, only about 15 percent of all households in Montana would qualify, because average wage in Montana is $23,037, lowest in nation; Villa, who makes $17,800 a year, pays virtually nothing in federal income tax, so she does not expect Bush's plan to change anything for her; still, Villa supports tax cut as do most people in Montana; photo (M)
docs.snippet: From the window of her apartment on a hill in Helena, Carrie Villa can see the Sleeping Giant, the mountain formation on the northern horizon that looks just like its name and holds the dream Ms. Villa has been nurturing through 10 hard years.    ''I...

docs.lead_paragraph: After two Mexican day laborers were badly beaten in Suffolk County in September, the region's long-simmering racial tensions were laid bare -- residents waving American flags clashed with brown-skinned immigrants, and a county legislator, Brian X. Foley, wrote a bill to try to bridge the divide. Now the Suffolk County executive, Robert J. Gaffney, has vetoed Mr. Foley's proposal to spend $80,000 to create a community support center for the laborers and sent it back to the Legislature with a message that county government should not pay for anything that would foster the hiring of undocumented workers.

headline.main: In Suffolk, Bill for Day Laborer Center Is Vetoed

docs.abstract: Suffolk County Exec Robert J Gaffney vetoes bill to spend $80,000 to create community support center for day laborers, and sends it back to County Legislature with message that county government should not pay for anything that would foster hiring of undocumented workers (M)
docs.snippet: After two Mexican day laborers were badly beaten in Suffolk County in September, the region's long-simmering racial tensions were laid bare -- residents waving American flags clashed with brown-skinned immigrants, and a county legislator, Brian X....

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives voted today to repeal the estate tax, a big item in President Bush's tax plan, but in the Senate the president's proposal for $1.6 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years appeared to be in jeopardy. A swing Republican, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, indicated that he was prepared to vote against the full tax cut, the president's top legislative priority, and that could mean there are too few votes in the tightly divided Senate to pass it.

headline.main: BUSH'S TAX PLAN GETS LIFT IN HOUSE, BUT SENATE BALKS

docs.abstract: House votes to repeal estate tax, big item in Pres Bush's tax plan, but his proposal for $1.6 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years appears to be in jeopardy in Senate; Sen James M Jeffords, swing Republican, indicates he is prepared to vote against full tax cut, which could mean too few votes in tightly divided Senate to pass measure; Jeffords favors cutting taxes by $1.25 trillion over 10 years to allow for more money in budget for education of disabled; in House, estate tax measure passes by vote of 274 to 154 after House rejects Democratic alternative that would have eliminated tax on three-quarters of estates that now owe it but would have retained tax on very largest ones; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The House of Representatives voted today to repeal the estate tax, a big item in President Bush's tax plan, but in the Senate the president's proposal for $1.6 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years appeared to be in jeopardy.    A swing Republican,...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was almost exactly a year ago, during a campaign appearance in Pennsylvania, that George W. Bush said: ''Every environmental issue confronts us with a duty to be good stewards. As we use nature's gifts, we must do so wisely. Prosperity will mean little if we leave future generations a world of polluted air, toxic lakes and rivers, and vanished forests.'' He said it with a straight face.

headline.main: In America; Public Health in Peril

docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says Pres Bush's decision to reneg on campaign pledge to seek reductions in carbon dioxide emissions, and his rejection of Kyoto accord, should not be suprise to anyone familiar with his record as governor of Texas, state with worst environmental record, according to Sierra Club; says there is also no surprise that Bush-Cheney administration is attempting to do serious damage to programs that help children, given fact that Texas never complied with consent decree requiring it to provide appropriate health care services to 1.5 million children eligible for Medicaid, and given Cheney's voting record while in Congress on matters related to children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There's not much Republican in arney Taylor Jr., but what little there is has been activated by the prospect of a large federal tax cut. Mr. Taylor voted for Al Gore and has a tendency to distress his accountant by using profits for a program to distribute computers to low-income families. But as the owner of a software company that has suffered reversals as the economy has declined, he thinks President Bush may have a point in trying to reduce tax rates.

headline.main: From Bumpy Road in Georgia, Favorable View of Bush Plan

docs.abstract: Article in series, Judging the Tax Cut, about how taxpayers at varying income levels would be affected by Bush tax cut proposal; first article focuses on Barney Taylor Jr of Atlanta, Ga, 32-year-old partner in software company that has fallen on hard times; Taylor, who is black, voted for Vice Pres Al Gore, disagreeing with Pres Bush's support for capital punishment, among other reasons; but he thinks Bush may have point in trying to reduce tax rates; he and his family would pay $1,000 less in annual federal taxes under administration's proposal; Taylor's wife is unimpressed with that figure; what excites Taylor is prospect that tax cut would allow more companies to create more jobs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK SAG HARBOR: SECRECY BILL IS PUT ASIDE -- The trustees of the village of Sag Harbor on Tuesday put aside a law to punish any village officer or employee who talks publicly about discussions in the board's executive sessions. Some trustees questioned what, if anything, could be considered too sensitive to be publicly discussed in the village of 2,100 people on Long Island's East End. An early draft of the bill, since rejected, sought to jail offenders for up to 15 days or fine them $250. The vote on a weaker version was called off after the State Committee on Open Government found such prohibitions of ''questionable legality,'' said Rosemarie Cary Winchell, the village clerk. Al Baker (NYT) BUFFALO: RIFLE USED IN KILLING IS TRACED -- A pawnshop owner in Nashville remembers selling a Russian-made rifle to a man identified by the F.B.I. as James C. Kopp, the former fugitive charged with the 1998 killing of a Buffalo-area doctor who performed abortions, according to a published report. The F.B.I. traced the rifle to the A-Z Pawn Shop in 1998, the report said. The shop's owner, Patricia Osborne, told agents that she sold the Russian SKS rifle on July 16, 1997, to a man who showed a Virginia driver's license with the name B. James Milton. Ms. Osborne told The Buffalo News in a telephone interview, ''I don't remember what it cost, but SKS rifles go anywhere from $50 to $200.'' (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your April 2 front-page article ''Medical Fees Are Often Higher for Patients Without Insurance'' implies that doctors charge uninsured patients artificially high fees. In our anesthesiology practice at MetroWest Medical Center in Framingham and Natick, Mass., we have long set fees for uninsured patients equal to the lowest rates paid by our insurance companies, which are deeply discounted. Those unable to pay but requiring our services are cared for without charge.

headline.main: Who Gets to Pay the Doctor's Bill?

docs.abstract: Dr Jonathan M Stein letter notes that his anesthesiology practice in Massachusetts sets fees for uninsured patients equal to lowest rates paid by his insurance companies
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your April 2 front-page article ''Medical Fees Are Often Higher for Patients Without Insurance'' implies that doctors charge uninsured patients artificially high fees.     In our anesthesiology practice at MetroWest Medical Center...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your April 2 front-page article about higher medical fees for the uninsured minority ignored the obvious inverse of the issue: lower medical and insurance costs for the majority. Negotiated fees and capitated payment systems are perhaps the primary reason that the health care industry has been able to keep costs under control while at the same time drastically increasing the quality of care with new drugs, procedures and equipment. These payment systems and the flow of patients they provide allow hospitals to charge less than what the procedures actually cost.

headline.main: Who Gets to Pay the Doctor's Bill?

docs.abstract: Robert H C Ralston letter on problem of higher medical fees for the uninsured minority (April 2 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Vice President Dick Cheney casting his first tie-breaking vote, President Bush's tax plan passed its first test today in the Senate. The 51-to-50 vote was on one of the sharpest issues dividing the parties: whether tax cuts or Medicare should take precedence.

headline.main: BUSH TAX CUT PLAN PASSES FIRST TEST IN A SPLIT SENATE

docs.abstract: Senate, with Vice Pres Dick Cheney breaking 50-50 deadlock, blocks Democratic proposal to reduce Pres Bush's $1.6 trillion tax cut by $158 billion over next 10 years and use money, along with $153 billion earmarked by Bush, to pay for prescription drug coverage under Medicare; vote comes on Republican plan that would potentially allow same amount of money to be spent on Medicare drug coverage but would not shift money out of tax cut; Senate then rejects Democratic proposal by 50-50 vote; Cheney did not vote on this measure because it lacked majority needed to pass Senate; photo (M)
